image.altText: Peter Dutton in the prime minister's courtyard

items.synopsis: As the government weighs whether to keep or replace Philip Lowe as RBA governor, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says two key candidates from Treasury and Finance should be ruled out of the running.

title.children: Former RBA governor says Dutton 'silly to rule out' candidates from Treasury and Finance as next Reserve Bank head

image.altText: Aerial shot of a rescue boat and a capsized fishing boat.

items.synopsis: A Geraldton man walks away injury-free after being rescued from his capsized boat off WA's midwest coast.

title.children: Fisherman lucky to be alive after being stranded offshore by king wave

image.altText: Observation cell Banksia Hill

items.synopsis: As more examples of the unlawful confinement of youth detainees come to light, it's time to end the vicious cycle, writes state political reporter Keane Bourke.

title.children: Imagine being locked in a tiny room for days. For these teenagers, it's reality

image.altText: Huw Edwards holding a sheet of paper sitting at a news desk

items.synopsis: The BBC presenter facing allegations he paid a young person thousands of pounds for sexually explicit photos is Huw Edwards, the BBC reports, citing a statement from his wife.

title.children: Highest-paid journalist at BBC, Huw Edwards, named as presenter accused of paying for explicit teen photos

image.altText: A smiling young man with a beard dressed in high vis pulls a beer from a tap from behind a bar.

items.synopsis: It's a long trek from anywhere, but Ongerup in Western Australia — population 114 — has a community that refuses to let the town die.

title.children: Why this small WA community banded together to buy the pub, supermarket, cafe and petrol station

image.altText: A 3D model of the building that burnt down in Surry Hills

items.synopsis: The century-old former hat factory caught fire on a Thursday afternoon. Within seven minutes of the first triple-0 call, the entire building, in the most densely populated part of Sydney, was an inferno.

title.children: Unravelling the inferno that reduced this century-old former hat factory to rubble

image.altText: Images of round metallic objects known as spherules

items.synopsis: Scientists from Harvard University have collected fragments believed to belong to a huge interstellar meteor, but PNG officials say the research was conducted within their waters without the required permits.

title.children: An exciting discovery leads to controversy as Harvard scientists collect fragments from interstellar meteor

image.altText: Two men, one older and one young, stand wearing Australia Post high-vis gear.

items.synopsis: Michael Richardson has Down syndrome, hearing loss and could not read — but he would not let that stop him landing a job at Australia Post.

title.children: Greg has worked at Australia Post for 17 years, and now his son is following in his footsteps

image.altText: A man in high-vis and a helmet on an e-scooter on a city street.

items.synopsis: Petition for heavier and more powerful e-scooters in WA after riders call out "unreasonable" laws.

title.children: If you can buy a car that can do 300kph, why not a faster e-scooter? Perth riders push for change

image.altText: Andrew and Nicola stand side by side on the Perth foreshore

items.synopsis: One of Australia's richest couples announce their separation but insist there will be no impact on their shared ventures, including mining giant Fortescue Metals Group.

title.children: Mining billionaires Andrew and Nicola Forrest announce break-up, insist 'no impact' on FMG operations

image.altText: Fighters of Wagner private mercenary group pose for a picture.

items.synopsis: Russian mercenary group Wagner reportedly hands over its weapons. What's next for the fighters and their leader after June's mutiny?

title.children: Wagner has handed over its weapons to Russia's military. What's next for the mercenary group?

image.altText: Putin KGB zelenskyy composite

items.synopsis: Vladimir Putin had already proved himself NATO's greatest recruiter, and this week's summit in Lithuania highlights just how heavily sought-after the exclusive club has become, writes John Lyons.

title.children: How the NATO summit showed off Zelenskyy's power and the lingering fear of KGB ideals

image.altText: man with black beanie, brown coat and glasses sits on bed on flatbed ute with pet dog

items.synopsis: In only four months, the Wimmera's only homelessness outreach worker has found more than 60 rough sleepers. Injured abattoir worker Shane is one of them — and the number of people like him is expected to "explode".

title.children: Shane sleeps on a ute tray at night. He pretends he's camping to save face

image.altText: Christopher Eubanks raises his fist and grits his teeth at Wimbledon.

items.synopsis: Christopher Eubanks' dream run may have ended but he has a slice of Wimbledon history it took 30 years to conquer, while Aryna Sabalenka showed her power game is going to be extremely difficult to overcome.

title.children: American rewrites Wimbledon record books in defeat as Medvedev admits to 'dangerous' on court act

image.altText: Man standing at kitchen bench

items.synopsis: Patrick Quintal purchased a home in the Vicinity complex in Canterbury two years ago. Last week he found out it had "potential serious defects".

title.children: Patrick bought an apartment two years ago. Now he could have to pay nearly $200k for repairs

image.altText: A woman and a child.

items.synopsis: Foodbank Australia is calling for more funding for school breakfast programs, with a growing number of families struggling to send children to school with full bellies.

title.children: Mum-of-10 forced to cut back on school lunches as food prices 'out of control'

image.altText: A man on a bike screams in join as he wins a race.

items.synopsis: Belgium's Jasper Philipsen claims his fourth Tour de France stage win as Australia's Jai Hindley remains in third overall.

title.children: Hindley remains in third overall as Philipsen again proves his sprint class at Tour de France

image.altText: an aerial shot of a 3D printed toilet block.

items.synopsis: A groundbreaking development is taking place in Dubbo, western NSW, that could alter the housing crisis gripping regional NSW.

title.children: 3D-printed toilet block built in a few days could open door to housing solutions

image.altText: Sarah Snook, Pedro Pascal and Aubrey Plaza.

items.synopsis: Australia's Sarah Snook is one of multiple Succession cast members to be nominated for an Emmy, with The White Lotus, The Last of Us, and Ted Lasso taking up the other top noms.

title.children: Emmy nominations: See the snubs and surprises as writers' strike threatens to delay ceremony

image.altText: A car park at an outback resort with a red cliff in background.

items.synopsis: A resort west of Alice Springs will close while owners negotiate a water pipeline to be built from a bore 18 kilometres away.

title.children: Outback resort closes after water transportation costs make facility economically unviable

image.altText: A designed image showing John Zeitoune, Jye West and a building bearing an ACU logo.

items.synopsis: The Australian Catholic University has launched an internal inquiry after the ABC discovered the founder of the company providing its on-campus security has been charged with corruption — and had a secret business relationship with an employee overseeing its security contract.

title.children: 'I was told to shut up': Australian Catholic University accused of ignoring concerns about security contractor

image.altText: A woman standing in front of a fire.

items.synopsis: Sarah Fisher wants to bring new life into the world but her fertility journey has been less than easy. Living off disability payments, she is struggling to pay for treatment and has spent thousands of dollars already only to be unsuccessful.

title.children: Sarah's rare disorder has meant her body has put up with a lot. She's now on a fertility journey but her fight isn't over yet

image.altText: composite garside and former partner

items.synopsis: Harry Garside's ex-girlfriend is charged with assault and stalking, a month after the Olympian's domestic assault case was dropped by police.

title.children: Former girlfriend of boxer Harry Garside charged with domestic violence offences

image.altText: Huw Edwards stands at a podium talking into a microphone

items.synopsis: Huw Edwards has been identified by his wife as the reporter accused of paying a teenager thousands of pounds for sexually explicit photos. Here's what we know.

title.children: Who is Huw Edwards, the BBC presenter accused of buying sexually explicit photos?

image.altText: Three children sit and play on electronic devices.

items.synopsis: New data from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission shows millions of consumers are paying more on power bills than they should.

title.children: Millions of Australian households paying too much for electricity, according to ACCC

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank branch in Melbourne's CBD

items.synopsis: The bosses of Westpac and Commonwealth Bank are facing the parliamentary economics committee, a day after ANZ and NAB executives were grilled over interest rates. Follow live.

title.children: Commonwealth Bank and Westpac face grilling over interest rates, US inflation slows, ASX higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Disney's board has voted to keep current CEO Bob Iger in the role until 2026 after extending his contract by two years, as the company battles long-term challenges to its film and TV business. Iger came out of retirement in 2022 to lead the firm again, less than a year after he retired. At the time, Iger said he would stay on for two more years to restore the business, while Disney searched for a replacement to Bob Chapek, who was pushed out from the company. Chapek was Iger's handpicked successor. "There is more to accomplish before this transformative work is complete," Iger said in a statement. Disney is still continuing to interview candidates while the company's streaming video business continues to lose money, and its TV business records declines in audiences. It follows Disney axing 7,000 jobs in February to save $US5.5 billion.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Disney boss Bob Iger to stay on until 2026

children.content: Disney's board has voted to keep current CEO
Bob Iger in the role until 2026
after extending his contract by two years, as the company battles long-term challenges to its film and TV business.
Iger came out of retirement in 2022 to lead the firm again, less than a year after he retired.
At the time, Iger said he would stay on for two more years to restore the business, while Disney searched for a replacement to Bob Chapek, who was pushed out from the company.
Chapek was Iger's handpicked successor.
"There is more to accomplish before this transformative work is complete," Iger said in a statement.
Disney is still continuing to interview candidates while the
company's streaming video business continues to lose money
, and its
TV business records declines in audiences
It follows
Disney axing 7,000 jobs
in February to save $US5.5 billion.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Embattled consultancy firm PwC has confirmed it had a second conflict of interest breach in the past five years, but it did not involve the misuse of information. PwC disclosed the information in answers to written questions on notice by Greens senator Barbara Pocock, who asked: How many disciplinary actions have been taken in relation to conflicts of interest and/or the misuse of government information in the past 5 years? Past 1 year? In its reply, PwC disclosed there were two courses of disciplinary actions : Based on our enquiries, we are aware that the firm has taken action in relation to two matters involving conflicts of interest and/or the misuse of government information in the past five years, including the Tax Practitioners Board matter in which disciplinary action was taken this year. The other matter occurred in 2018. That action is separate to the current scandal engulfing PwC, involving the use of confidential government information to help clients evade proposed tax changes, which resulted in the sale of its government services division for $1. In a statement, PwC said the 2018 matter equated to an "internal protocol breach". "There is no second misuse of information breach ," a PwC spokesman said. "PwC, like other firms, was asked about disciplinary actions and PwC confirmed it had taken discipline against a partner over an internal process oversight where the partner did not obtain approval for an exclusivity undertaking in an engagement." The 2018 conflict of interest involved a PwC partner entering an exclusivity deal with a client without first seeking approval from PwC's conflict of interest team. The partner received a financial penalty, and was not fired from PwC. Public hearings into the inquiry into consulting services are set to resume in Canberra next wek.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC confirms second conflict of interest breach

PwC
has confirmed it had a
second conflict of interest breach in the past five years
, but it did not involve the misuse of information.
PwC disclosed the information in answers to written questions on notice by
Greens senator Barbara Pocock
, who asked:
How many disciplinary actions have been taken in relation to conflicts of interest and/or the misuse of government information in the past 5 years? Past 1 year?
In its reply,
PwC disclosed there were two courses of disciplinary actions
Based on our enquiries, we are aware that
the firm has taken action in relation to two matters
involving conflicts of interest and/or the misuse of government information in the past five years, including the Tax Practitioners Board matter in which disciplinary action was taken this year.
The other matter occurred in 2018

That action is separate to the current scandal engulfing PwC, involving the use of confidential government information to help clients evade proposed tax changes, which resulted in the sale of its government services division for $1.
In a statement, PwC said the 2018 matter equated to an "internal protocol breach".
"There is
no second misuse of information breach
," a PwC spokesman said.
"PwC, like other firms, was asked about disciplinary actions and
PwC confirmed it had taken discipline against a partner
over an internal process oversight
where the partner did not obtain approval for an exclusivity undertaking in an engagement."
The 2018 conflict of interest involved a PwC partner entering an exclusivity deal with a client without first seeking approval from PwC's conflict of interest team.
The partner received a financial penalty, and was not fired from PwC.
Public hearings into the inquiry into consulting services are set to resume in Canberra next wek.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Peter Dutton says two of the government's potential picks to replace Philip Lowe as Reserve Bank governor would not be able to operate independently because of their established relationships with government. Treasury secretary Steven Kennedy and Finance secretary Jenny Wilkinson are among the candidates being floated to become the next RBA governor, as speculation mounts over whether the government will extend Lowe's term or replace him when it expires in September. But Dutton said the treasury and finance bosses should be ruled out of the running. "We can't have a situation where the government is appointing somebody who is familiar to the government, in the sense they have worked very closely with ministers, or the treasurer or the finance minister," Dutton said. "We can't have somebody who has been appointed by the Labor Party or indeed the Coalition to a senior position within government. It needs to be somebody who is independent and has the best interests of the Australian public in mind." You can keep reading this story from political reporter Jake Evans below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton says two candidates should be ruled out of being considered for RBA governor

featuredLink.title: Peter Dutton says two candidates to become next RBA governor should be ruled out of consideration

children.content: Peter Dutton says two of the government's potential picks to replace
Philip Lowe
as
Reserve Bank governor
would not be able to operate independently because of their established relationships with government.
Treasury secretary Steven Kennedy
and
Finance secretary Jenny Wilkinson
are among the candidates being floated to become the next RBA governor, as speculation mounts over whether the government will extend Lowe's term or replace him when it expires in September.
But Dutton said the treasury and finance bosses should be ruled out of the running.

"We can't have a situation where the government is appointing somebody who is familiar to the government, in the sense they have worked very closely with ministers, or the treasurer or the finance minister," Dutton said.

"We can't have somebody who has been appointed by the Labor Party or indeed the Coalition to a senior position within government. It needs to be somebody who is independent and has the best interests of the Australian public in mind."
You can keep reading this story from
political reporter Jake Evans
below:

image.altText: Gender dysphoria

items.synopsis: One of Australia's leading medical insurers dumps cover for private practising doctors who initiate hormone treatment in adolescents with gender dysphoria, a decision that may put even more pressure on public hospital waiting lists.

title.children: Medical insurer drops cover for doctors who initiate hormone treatments in adolescents with gender dysphoria

image.altText: A woman wearing a bright yellow face mask look down at a nurse putting a sticker bandaid on her arm after a vaccination.

items.synopsis: Flu vaccine uptake in recent months across Australia is almost 2 million down on what it was last year, with experts blaming COVID 'fatigue' and cost-of-living pressures. Two students have died from influenza this week, including an 11-year-old Queensland girl and a teenager from NSW.

title.children: Flu vaccine uptake is down, and experts say COVID 'fatigue' and cost-of-living are to blame

image.altText: Hayley Atwell, a white brunette woman, and Tom Cruise, a white brunette middle-aged man, are in a car looking at the rear window

items.synopsis: The now late-middle-aged Ethan Hunt returns with his posse of sidekick operatives to take down a menacing sentient AI — and a few past foes — one analog stunt at a time.

title.children: Mission Impossible 7 promised Tom Cruise’s irresistibly deranged Hollywood charm — did it deliver?

items.synopsis: The performer, whose real name is Ryuji Higa, was a media personality, model and activist.

title.children: Japanese influencer and LGBTQ advocate found dead in Tokyo office

items.synopsis: The latest test sparks a United Nations Security Council meeting and condemnation from world leaders.

title.children: North Korea launches latest missile test, warning of 'nuclear crisis beyond the Cold War era'

image.altText: A female AI news reader in a headscarf in a studio.

items.synopsis: Several countries across Asia are now welcoming AI news readers to their screens to present daily bulletins. Could Australia be willing to let digital bots pose as presenters?

title.children: AI news readers are becoming more common across Asia. Will Australia follow suit?
